Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Investigating How Stoicism Influences Empathy for Pain: A Cross-Cultural Neuroimaging Study
Award.AbstractNarration:
Brain imaging studies have demonstrated that empathy, an adaptive and often automatic process occurring when we view pain in others, may be influenced by social and cultural factors. Stoicism, or the endurance of discomfort without outward expression, is a factor relevant to pain perception that is known to differ between East Asian and Western individuals. This project will use neuroimaging to test whether culturally variable beliefs about stoicism influence empathy for pain in a sample of Chinese and American individuals. The data from this project will prove useful in understanding how social and cultural factors influence empathy. Research will be performed in collaboration with Dr. Shihui Han in the Culture and Social Cognitive Neuroscience Laboratory at Peking University. Dr. Han is an expert in the social and cultural neuroscience of empathy.

This award supports a cross-cultural neuroimaging study in China and the United States to investigate the effect of stoicism beliefs on empathy and to identify neurobiological mechanisms of the hypothesized effect. The experiment will use functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to measure brain activity during an emotion regulation task in response to negative and neutral images. The experiment will also measure the neural empathic response to pain in others. The experimenter will test 1) if differences in stoicism beliefs predict differences in the emotion regulation strategy of expressive suppression, and 2) if differences in neural activity during suppression explain variation in the neural empathic response to pain. The data collected from participants in China will be compared to results from participants in the United States. By comparing functional brain activity during an emotion regulation task with the neural empathic response to pain in a cross-cultural sample, this research will contribute to our understanding of how culturally variable beliefs about pain influence empathic responding.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and China's Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This National Science Foundation East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes (NSF EAPSI) Fellowship, titled Investigating How Stoicism Influences Empathy for Pain: A Cross-Cultural Neuroimaging Study, successfully resulted in the completion of research milestones in Beijing, China in Summer 2017. As part of this project, two functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) tasks were developed to assess brain activity related to empathy for pain and stoicism to faces and emotional scenes. In collaboration with Dr. Shihui Han’s Culture and Social Cognitive Neuroscience Laboratory at Peking University, a total of 30 participants have completed the neuroimaging study to date. The goals of the project are to test two main research questions: 1) Does stoicism (operationalized as the emotion regulation strategy of expressive suppression) influence the neural empathic response to pain in others? 2) Does the type of stimulus (face vs. emotional scene) influence expressive suppression-related brain activity? An additional research question in the scope of this project, to be addressed upon collection of a U.S. sample of individuals in Dr. Elizabeth Losin's Social & Cultural Neuroscience Laboratory at the University of Miami, is whether there are cross-cultural differences in the use of expressive suppression and the relationship between expressive suppression and empathy for pain. Below is a summary of this project’s findings to date.

  • Addressing our first research question of whether expressive suppression influences the neural empathic response to pain, in a region-of-interest (ROI) analysis we found that passively viewing pain versus neutral expression faces resulted in increased brain activity in the right anterior insula (rAI), a region previously implicated in empathy for pain. Analysis of the expressive suppression condition revealed activation in the right amygdala and right inferior frontal gyrus (rIFG), regions previously associated with expressive suppression. In a correlation analysis, we found that activity within the rAI was negatively correlated with activity in the right amygdala and rIFG. This result preliminarily suggests that increased expressive suppression-related brain activity may be associated with a decreased neural empathic response to pain. Future analyses are planned to investigate this relationship further.
  • Addressing our second research question of whether the type of stimulus (face vs. emotional scene) influences expressive suppression-related brain activity, we found more common recruitment of prefrontal cortical areas in the late versus early period of expressive suppression to both emotional faces and emotional scene pictures, as well as evidence that expressive suppression to faces results in an increase in amygdala activity temporally earlier than expressive suppression to emotional scene pictures.
  • We plan to address our cross-cultural research question, which concerns potential cross-cultural differences in the use of expressive suppression and the relationship between expressive suppression and empathy for pain, upon collection of a sample of subjects in the U.S. at the University of Miami.

Overall, the results of this international collaborative project suggest that neural empathy for pain may be modulated by engaging in the emotion regulation strategy of expressive suppression. Specifically, our preliminary results indicate a possible overall negative relationship between empathy for pain and expressive suppression, with greater expressive suppression-related brain activity associated with decreased neural empathy for pain. This finding is congruent with the view of empathy for pain as a primarily affective phenomenon, in that the suppression of external facial responses to others’ pain may serve to also dampen the neural empathic response to pain in others. In addition, this study examined differences in the use of expressive suppression depending on the type of stimulus perceived. Examining the temporal aspects of expressive suppression to two types of images, we found evidence that expressive suppression may have different consequences at different times depending on the stimulus perceived. Future research will build upon these findings and focus on the broader relationship between internal emotion regulation processes and empathy for pain in others, with a particular focus on the role that cultural beliefs regarding emotional expressivity may play in this relationship. This work has the potential to positively impact society by better understanding the factors that influence the socially valuable phenomenon of empathy.
